rows.title: Body Scan

transcript.eng:
Today's pause is called a body scan. Begin by closing your eyes or maintaining a soft gaze. 
Take a full breath in and a long breath out.
Now, bringing awareness to the top of your body,
your head,
face,
neck,
shoulders.
Noticing any sensations, movements, any places of holding. 
Continue to scan your body, moving down the arms and hands and into your fingers.
Sense the back of your body and your lower back. 
Feeling the contact of your body with the chair if you are seated. 
Now, sensing your upper legs, your lower legs, and the feet. 
Take a full, deep breath in and a long breath out. Finish this pause by opening your eyes. 

Thank you for taking a moment to pause with us. It's time for today's lesson.

rows.transcript:
Today's pause is called a body scan. Begin by closing your eyes or maintaining a soft gaze. 
Take a full breath in and a long breath out.
Now, bringing awareness to the top of your body,
your head,
face,
neck,
shoulders.
Noticing any sensations, movements, any places of holding. 
Continue to scan your body, moving down the arms and hands and into your fingers.
Sense the back of your body and your lower back. 
Feeling the contact of your body with the chair if you are seated. 
Now, sensing your upper legs, your lower legs, and the feet. 
Take a full, deep breath in and a long breath out. Finish this pause by opening your eyes. 

Thank you for taking a moment to pause with us. It's time for today's lesson.

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Wonderful, I am so happy! Keep up the good work.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Sorry that things are difficult. All families struggle. @global.app_name is here to help!

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Whatever went ‘wrong’ today, let it go and try again tomorrow. It is okay!

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Wonderful, I am so happy! Keep up the good work.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: Sorry that things are difficult. All families struggle. @global.app_name is here to help!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Whatever went ‘wrong’ today, let it go and try again tomorrow. It is okay!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today we are learning about giving our children praise. 

Praise is good for building positive relationships, and is also helpful at encouraging good behaviour!

Well done for taking time to learn how to strengthen your relationship with your child. It shows you really care!

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: That's great! Being praised often makes us feel proud.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: That's great! Being praised often makes us feel happy!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Sometimes being praised makes us feel embarrassed, usually because we are not used to it. It will get easier with practice! Giving praise helps children learn the behaviours you want to see.
rows.quiz_1_question: How did the message above make you feel?
rows.quiz_1_feedback_4: Sometimes, when we are praised for actions that we don't feel we deserve, we get sad. It is okay to feel sad, but remember that just being here is worthy of praise! Keep your chin up!
rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today we are learning about giving our children praise. 

Praise is good for building positive relationships, and is also helpful at encouraging good behaviour!

Well done for taking time to learn how to strengthen your relationship with your child. It shows you really care!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
We all feel better when we are praised.

Praising your child when they behave well will make them want to behave that way more often. 

It also creates a positive and loving relationship between you.

Begin by praising your child during your one-on-one time.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
We all feel better when we are praised.

Praising your child when they behave well will make them want to behave that way more often. 

It also creates a positive and loving relationship between you.

Begin by praising your child during your one-on-one time.
rows.media_title: How will it help me and my family?
rows.media_transcript:
Greetings, everyone.

When was the last time you were praised? Can you praise yourself for something right now? Praise makes us all feel good. 

It is good to praise our children when they have done well, because when we do that, they will do more of that good behaviour we want to see.

And let's remember to praise ourselves too, for big or small things!

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s see how a mother praises her son, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name during one-on-one time.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let’s see how a mother praises her son, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name during one-on-one time.
rows.text_2: @data.characters.f3_mother.name: “You found one striped sock and one with dots. Let’s find socks that match.”
@data.characters.f3_mother.name: “Another sock! This one is white. It’s frustrating to try to find a matching pair when there are so many clothes to look through.”
@data.characters.f3_mother.name: “You are being very patient and looking very hard, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name. Well done for trying. I am happy you are helping me.”

@data.characters.f3_mother.name: “You found two socks with the same pattern! Well done for not giving up, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name! 

Because you helped me so well, I now have 5 extra minutes to play with you. What would you like to play?”

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s reflect on what we saw.

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Exactly! When @data.characters.f3_mother.name praises @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, he feels good about himself.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: Not exactly, but the praise does help him deal with his frustration. When @data.characters.f3_mother.name praises @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, they want to keep looking for the socks!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Not exactly, but the praise will help him want to help more often. When @data.characters.f3_mother.name praises @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, he will remember being praised and be more likely to help with chores in the future!
rows.quiz_1_option_1_text: To boost his self-esteem and confidence
rows.quiz_1_option_2_text: To make him feel good about himself.
rows.quiz_1_option_3_text: To encourage him to work harder
rows.text_1_facilitator: Let’s reflect on what we saw.
rows.quiz_2_question: What can we learn from @data.characters.f3_mother.name in how she praises @data.characters.f3_son_4.name?
rows.quiz_2_option_1_text: She yells so he is sure to hear her.
rows.quiz_2_feedback_1: False. @data.characters.f3_mother.name doesn’t yell at all but she does go down to @data.characters.f3_son_4.name’s level. This is important so she can connect to him. @data.characters.f3_mother.name’s actions show us that the way we give praise is also important.
rows.quiz_2_option_2_text: She uses his name and makes eye contact
rows.quiz_2_feedback_2: True! All @data.characters.f3_mother.name’s actions show us that the way we give praise is also important.
rows.quiz_2_option_3_text: She tells him he is a “good boy”.
rows.quiz_2_feedback_3: False. @data.characters.f3_mother.name praises her son for something specific and provides the praise immediately. This shows us that the way we give praise  is important for it to be effective.
rows.quiz_2_option_4_text: She praises him for the process of trying and not for the result.
rows.quiz_2_feedback_4: True! All @data.characters.f3_mother.name’s actions show us that the way we give praise is also important.
rows.quiz_2_option_5_text: She does not criticise his mistake
rows.quiz_2_feedback_5: True! All @data.characters.f3_mother.name’s actions show us that how we give praise is also important.
rows.quiz_3_question: Why does @data.characters.f3_mother.name give @data.characters.f3_son_4.name a hug and extra playtime together?
rows.quiz_3_feedback_1: The hug does show love, but it also rewards him for helping with a chore. Giving a simple reward helps our children to do things that may be difficult for them again.
rows.quiz_3_option_2_text: So that he knows that he doesn’t have to help anymore again.
rows.quiz_3_feedback_2: Actually, the hug will encourage him to help again next time! Giving a simple reward helps our children to do things that may be difficult for them again.
rows.quiz_3_option_3_text: To encourage him to stay patient
rows.quiz_3_feedback_3: That’s right, giving a simple reward helps our children to do things that may be difficult for them again.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Here are some easy tips for how to use praise:

rows.text_1_facilitator: Here are some easy tips for how to use praise:
rows.section_1_text: Look for anything good or helpful that your child does or tries to do when you want to praise them.
rows.section_1_extra_text:
Pause and really notice when they are doing something positive. Even if it’s expected of them.

Praise your child for *trying*. This boosts their self-esteem and confidence, which helps them to learn new behaviours.
rows.section_2_text: Praise them when you see them do something you like. Do this every day – even if it’s something really small.
rows.section_2_extra_text:
Tell them specifically what they have done well.

Be enthusiastic and really mean it!

You can show your praise with a big smile and words.
rows.section_3_text: Give your child a simple, free reward to encourage them to do more of the behaviours that you have praised them for.
rows.section_3_extra_text:
Rewards should be simple and free. 

Give your child a hug, extra playtime together, or make their favourite meal. 

Simple rewards can be a big motivation for your child to keep trying and show more positive behaviour.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Curious to see how praise can help you and your family?

Your home activity is to praise your child for 3 things every day, and praise yourself too for all your hard work being a parent – you deserve it!

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Yes, you can praise them for these behaviours… and many more!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: Yes, you can praise them for these behaviours… and many more!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Yes, you can praise them for these behaviours… and many more!
rows.quiz_1_question:
What is one behaviour your child regularly shows in their daily routine that you can praise them for?
There are lots of right answers to this one!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_4: Yes, you can praise them for these behaviours… and many more!
rows.text_1_facilitator:
Curious to see how praise can help you and your family?

Your home activity is to praise your child for 3 things every day, and praise yourself too for all your hard work being a parent – you deserve it!
rows.quiz_2_question: Remember to also praise yourself for the good work you're doing! What’s one way you can reward yourself for your hard work as a parent?
rows.quiz_2_option_1_text: Treat yourself to something you enjoy (e.g., a favourite snack or activity)
rows.quiz_2_feedback_1: Great choice! Taking time to enjoy something you love is a wonderful way to recharge and recognize your efforts as a parent.
rows.quiz_2_option_2_text: Take a few minutes to relax (e.g., meditation, a short walk, or just some quiet time)
rows.quiz_2_feedback_2: Well done! Giving yourself a moment to relax is so important. You’re doing a great job, and it’s okay to take a break.
rows.quiz_2_option_3_text: Celebrate by acknowledging your achievements (e.g.talking to a friend)
rows.quiz_2_feedback_3: Fantastic! Reflecting on your accomplishments helps you see how much you’re doing right. You deserve to celebrate your hard work!
rows.quiz_2_feedback_4: Do something fun with your child that you both enjoy
rows.quiz_2_option_5_text: Wonderful choice! Sharing a fun activity with your child not only rewards you but also strengthens your bond. You’re doing an amazing job!
rows.quiz_1_option_5_text: Getting ready for school or bed
rows.quiz_1_feedback_5: Yes, you can praise them for these behaviours… and many more!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_6: Yes, you can praise them for these behaviours… and many more!
rows.quiz_2_feedback_6: Great idea! However you choose to reward yourself, it’s important to acknowledge the effort you put into parenting. You deserve it!
